theory.intro.latestText: <par>We know how to <skill-link>expand brackets</skill-link> like <inline-math/>. But what do we do if we have a multiplication of brackets with brackets? Like <inline-math/>? The answer is: we <term>expand brackets twice</term>. First we expand one, and then we expand the other.</par>

theory.rule.oldText: <head>The rule</head><par>If we have a number multiplication, like for instance <inline-math/>, then we can visualize this multiplication using blocks.</par><block-drawing/><par>From this, we see that <inline-math/> can be rewritten to <inline-math/>. Check for yourself: both result into <inline-math/>.</par><par>This works exactly the same if we have an expression like <inline-math/>. Here, <inline-math/>, <inline-math/> and <inline-math/> can be any type of expression, like <inline-math/> or anything similar. We can again visualize this.</par><block-drawing/><par>From this visualization, we see that we may rewrite <inline-math/> to <inline-math/>. We call this <term>expanding the brackets</term>. The accompanying rule is <block-math/> Note that we multiply the factor outside of the brackets (here <inline-math/>) separately with each of the terms inside the brackets (here <inline-math/> and <inline-math/>).</par>
theory.rule.latestText: <head>The rule</head><par>If we have a number multiplication, like for instance <inline-math/>, then we can visualize this multiplication using blocks.</par><block-drawing/><par>From this, we see that <inline-math/> can first be rewritten to <inline-math/> and then to <inline-math/>. Check for yourself: they all result into <inline-math/>.</par><par>This works exactly the same if we have an expression like <inline-math/>. Here, <inline-math/>, <inline-math/>, <inline-math/> and <inline-math/> can be any type of expression, like <inline-math/> or anything similar. We can again visualize this.</par><block-drawing/><par>From this visualization, we see that we may rewrite <inline-math/> to <inline-math/>. We call this <term>expanding double brackets</term>. The accompanying rule is <block-math/> You generally don't need to remember this rule. What you should remember is that you multiply each of the terms from the left brackets (here <inline-math/> and <inline-math/>) with each of the terms from the right brackets (here <inline-math/> and <inline-math/>). If you do this for all combinations of terms, you get the right result.</par>

theory.steps.oldText: The stepsTo expand double brackets, like for instance with , take the following steps.Expand the left brackets. (Or identically, you may start with the right set too.) Keep the other brackets as they are, treating them as a single number. For the example, this gives For each of the resulting terms, simplify any potential number multiplications. So becomes and becomes .Also merge any multiplications of equal factors into powers. So becomes .The final result is as easy as you can possibly write it.
theory.steps.latestText: The stepsTo expand double brackets, like for instance with , take the following steps.Expand the left brackets. (Or identically, you may start with the right set too.) Keep the other brackets as they are, treating them as a single number. For the example, this gives Continue by expanding the remaining brackets. For our example, this then givesNote that we can also use a short-cut by directly multiplying each of the terms of the left brackets with each of the terms of the right brackets.Merge similar terms - terms that are identical, apart from their number factor - into a single term. In the example, we merge and together into .The final result is as easy as you can possibly write it.

practice.basicForm.mainProblem.latestText: Consider the expression <block-math/> Expand the brackets and simplify the result as much as possible.

practice.basicForm.step1.problem.oldText: Take the factor outside of the bracket (here <inline-math/>) and multiply it separately with each of the terms within the brackets (<inline-math/> and <inline-math/>).
practice.basicForm.step1.problem.latestText: Expand the left set of brackets (here <inline-math/>) while keeping right set of brackets (here <inline-math/>) intact. Treat the right set of brackets as a single number, which technically it is.

practice.basicForm.step1.solution.oldText: If we set up the two multiplications, keeping a plus in-between, we wind up with <block-math/>
practice.basicForm.step1.solution.latestText: We multiply each of the terms <inline-math/> and <inline-math/> in the left set of brackets by the full right brackets. This results in <block-math/>

practice.basicForm.step2.problem.oldText: Where possible, inside each term, merge products of numbers together into a single factor.

practice.basicForm.step2.solution.oldText: Both terms have a multiplication of two numbers. We can simplify both of them. This gives us <block-math/>
practice.basicForm.step2.solution.latestText: Expanding the remaining brackets in the usual way results in <block-math/>

practice.basicForm.step3.problem.oldText: Where possible, inside each term, merge products of equal factors into a power.
practice.basicForm.step3.problem.latestText: Merge similar terms (with equal power of <inline-math/>) together to simplify the result as much as possible.

practice.basicForm.step3.solution.oldText: We can turn the multiplication of <inline-math/> with itself into <inline-math/>. This turns the full expression into <block-math/> This is our final answer. In short, <inline-math/>.
practice.basicForm.step3.solution.latestText: There are two terms that have <inline-math/> as a factor, being <inline-math/> and <inline-math/>. Together these can be written as <inline-math/>. The resulting expression then becomes <block-math/> This is our final answer. In short, <inline-math/>.

practice.basicForm.step1.problem.wrongBr.latestText: You have not expanded the left brackets <inline-math/> yet.

practice.basicForm.feedback.wrongBracket.latestText: You have not expanded the left brackets yet.
